Very nice hoppy aroma, grassy. Fresh; correct malt, strong and aromatic hopping. Excellent!
Cask at Mahars. Earthy cask flavors, not much hop or malt, but it was balanced. The hops that were there were pleasant, but why call this beer hophead?

Cask at D.B.A. Yellow/golden color with a good sized white head. Aroma of citrus hops, pine and a bit of malt. Well balanced flavor starting with some sweet malt and finishing with mild hop bitterness. Very drinkable.
Guest beer at Staggs Musselburgh. Nice looking beer, head lasts well. Nicely balanced malt/hops on the palate, with an average finish, not bad.

Cask at the Market Porter, London: Pours a clear bright golden with a dense, but thin and well-lacing head.  Aroma has lots of fresh piney hops and some subtle dry caramel.  Body starts semi-sweet, floral, and hoppy with a nice malty balance and smooth palate.  Finishes crisp and bittersweet.  A very nice, incredibly drinkable beer.

Floral, grapefruit, pine, orange hops in the nose with some lightly toasty underlying malt sweetness.  Clear blonde body with a lasting white head.  Chewy, biscuity malt flavours with grapefruit-citrus and pine hop flavour and pleasant balancing bitterness in the dry finish.  Medium-light body with moderate, crisp carbonation.  Cask at GBBF 2005.

Cask, Peterborough Fest 05.  Light gold in colour.  Aromas are bitter, fresh green pine with some sweet maltiness and pepper.  Flavours are citrus fruit with grassy fresh hops.  As hoppy as expected with a dry finish.  Light, simple and refreshing.

Cask @ GBBF 2005: Golden coloured. Clear. White dense head. Fruit, hops and sweetness in the nose.  Has some herbal and flowery fruityness in the flaovur. Orangy and smooth. Has a very nice bitterness in the end. Is clean and crisp. Very good one.
Cask at GBBF 2005. Pale golden beer with excellent firm head. Glorious flowery aroma. Buttery, fruity taste and a good touch of dryness. Brilliant.

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2006  Cask at County Hotel JDW, Ashford. One of my favourite all time beers. Golden in colour with wonderful citrus, grassy, hoppy flavours.  The malt gives it some red berry notes and the finish is long and hoppy and dry.  Simply fantastic session beer I can drink all night.  4.7/5

Re-rate, gravity dispense cask at Butchers Arms, Herne. The grapefruit sherbert hop is stunning.

[cask at dba NY] when an American sees the term "hophead" attached to the name of a beer, he gets certain expectations - the American, used to the brutal, "unrefined," palate-assaulting, paint-peeling flavor of a Dreadnaught and a Ruination expects that something named Hophead brings the promise of a mouth-puckering attack of hops - the American, obviously a plebeian that doesnt appreciate the subtle nuances of a good golden ale, remarks, "this doesnt taste like much of anything at all; where the hell are the hops?" - yes, there are some very subtle touches of grapfruit and grain, but, he thinks, "cant the British make anything besides Bitters and Golden Ales, I mean, really, come on."  But the American just doesnt know what hes talking about.  His palate is ruined by all of those high gravity American monstrosities that shouldnt even be called beer, what with their deviations from tradition and sense of experimentation.  A pox on them all!

(cask-conditioned at Olver Twist, Stockholm) Golden with a low creamy head. Hoppy and aromatic aroma of lemon and grapefruit. Lots of grapefruit in the flavour, hints of lemon. Firm malt charcter. Grapefruity bitter finish.
[Cask conditioned at Wenlock Arms] Golden coloured. Very hoppy and flowery. Bitter finish. Creamy mouthfeel. Light and refreshing.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2005 Cask conditioned at NERAX 4/28/2005 while chatting with the brewerLight blonde with tints of lime-green.  Small white head, recedes to light foam.  Aroma of light hops, grassy, mildly herbal, maybe some oregano and lime in there. . .Flavor of pale malt, bitter lemonpeel, minty at times, some hints of limes, oranges.  Tingly carbonation, bit of honey, eminently drinkable stuff.

UPDATED: DEC 24, 2015 
Aug, 2003 Gravity, Frog & Toad Body Parts Beer Festival.  Blond Ale. A lemon or Chardonnay colour - quite attractive for a blonde. Fragrant floral hops. Gentle citric tang - mostly soft grapefruit sprinkled with brown sugar, but theres an element of orange and a hint of vanilla pod just dipped into the brew. Light to medium body - refreshing and satisfying. Finishes soft with a long lingering dryness. Spanking. The beer of the festival. [4.0]
March, 2005 Dog & Bone, Gillingham.  Foam head and creamy texture because the beer was pulled through a sparkler. White lilly aroma. Vanilla and caramel and oily hops. Served cool. Sparkler spoils the beer. [3.2]
June, 2005 JDW, Boston, Lincs. Fresh & fruity with passion fruit and citric notes. This is a great beer, but it does like to be well treated to show its best bits. [3.4]
July, 2009 Darnly Arms, Cobham Lovely soapy drink. Slight toffee - milk toffee. [3.3]
Christmas Eve, 2015 500ml dark bottle, filtered, from Asda or Tesco. I like this when served in top condition from the cask. As it is a delicate, soft beer, best served fresh, its not so good when not kept well, or when not too fresh. Filtered in the bottle its fairly flat and ordinary, with the hops dominating to the extent that the malt is barely present.  Each to their own - some people are not interested in malt flavour and character, preferring the taste of hops; but if, like me, you enjoy malt, then ignore the bottle, and seek out the cask - theres really no comparison. [2.6]

This was my favorite of all the Dark Star beers I saw on tap the last time I was over in the UK. It aims to combine hops like some of the American micros are doing but the bitterness that comes out is tasty and not overpowering. It aims to please rather than overstimulate the senses.
[Cask at The Evening Star, Brighton] An orange beer with no head. The aorm is very grassy and hoppy while the flavor is sweet grassy with a dry hoppy end and a thin body.
Cask at the Battersea Beer Festival 2005. Another good blond ale which seem to be rather popular here at the moment. Citrus hoppy aroma, bitter, flowery. Very dry finish, excellent beer.
Clear gold with a white head, nice lace. Hoppy citrus and grapefruit aroma. Sweet biscuity malt with a nice citric hop kick behind it. Quite dry, very refreshing. Full bodied smooth. Nice.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2011 Hand pulled at the Head of Steam, Euston. Yellow, with a medium head. Fresh aroma. Very tasty Blond ale, full of hoppy, dry notes. Crispy throughout the pint, gently becoming more rounded. Less juicy than I remember, but still one of the best of the style and a great session ale. (6/12/2004). RE-RATE: To make up for my low original rating, I wish to acknowledge the blisteringly good pint of Hophead I greedily supped on Wednesday. What a way to roll back the years: bright yellow, squelchy citrus freshness, with beautiful hop length. This deserves a 4.1, so thats what it can have. (original score was 3.7).
Cask conditioned at the Twickenham Beer Festival. This beer is rather pale, light bodied, very hoppy & full of citrus.

The colour is clear yellow with a tint of gold. The foam is finger-think, white and built by small bubbles. 

The smell is very weak, but I could perceive some strains of leaven.

The carbonation is mild.

The taste is dominated by newly baked loaf and sour fruit drops. The aftertaste contains a buttery bitterness with hints of pineapple and grapefruits. The whole experience got a slight chemical touch.

When I look through this review, I find it more negative than I intended. I think that this ale is quite OK, but it had some small details that just didnt work together. It may be a case of a cask on its way to go skunky
Pale ale with a dry/slightly malty aroma and dry flavour.  Overall a plain pale beer.
A pale ale witha lovely grapefruit aroma. A burst of hops hits the taste buds leading to  a satisfying bitter finish. As rated by <A HREF=http://www.qualityales.com>Quality Ales

Nice one, quite light, but covers the palate nicely, aromatic hops, orangey, flowery, great balance, and lots of flavour for a beer with only 3.8%ABV.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2014 Cask conditioned - handpump - Evening Star Brighton.  An extremly light golden colour to this beer which has a very hoppy aroma predominantly of grapefruit.  The taste is also very hoppy like some American IPAs; however the nose is stronger. Cask Conditioned @ Reading Festival and elsewhere. A modern American style bitter that bursts the floodbanks, breaks through the heart and bleeds citric juice all over the place. High and mighty and standing proud as a wounded soldier.
Cask conditioned @ Reading Beer Festival. Floral grapefruit hop attack. A touch of malty sweetness but the hops rule. SImple but oh so nice. Spritzy carnonation spoils the refreshing body.
UPDATED: MAY 5, 2004 Cask @ Oliver Twist, Stockholm Golden ale with an aroma of exotic fruits. Rather complex for its strength. Refreshing with a long hoppy aftertaste.
On cask at Redbones:  Clear orange with no head.  Light fruits with some citrus and caramel.  Medium bodied, starts and ends slightly bitter.

Cask, NERAX 04 festival, Somerville, Ma. Good nose, pineapple,apricot, vanilla. Yellow gold color. Kinda floral, though I got a sourdough , metallic thing too. Thin & bitter finish. Nose was my favorite part.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Cask, Battersea Beer Festival, London 2004: Golden, no head, weak toffee nose - butterscotch like. Also in taste, sweet and hoppy at the same time. ot my favorite.

Unlike another beer of the same name at the same festival (Brewsters Hophead q.v.) this one is hoppy, in an aromatic sort of way. Obvious Cascade presence. Softish, but dry, finish. Overall, very acceptable. Cask (handpump), Battersea Beer Festival.

Cask Conditioned, at the Wenlock Arms, London.  Pale golden coloured body, with a slight, lacy white head. Crystal clear condition. Very fruity, hoppy aroma. Pineapple and pears. Nice hop bite to it but with a short palate and low bitterness, it got an unexpected finish. Nice easily quaffable beer.

Sampled cask conditioned at Akkurat, Stockholm.
Golden colour. Strong citrusy hop aroma. Sweet and light bodied. Soft and gently rounded, flowery, very bitter finsih. Very elegant with malt profile. Packed with flavour, oh god is this beer really only 3.8%? A glorious beer served in perfect condition.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2015 Cask Conditioned at The Evening Star, Brighton.
Light in colour, this is a little beauty of a session bitter. Packed with tasty light hops, refreshing to drink, would be great for a full session.
UPDATED: AUG 29, 2010 Pale straw colour.  The aroma is floral, lightly fruity-citrusy.  Fresh and lightly bitter, with citrusy-fruity notes and a quenching acidity.  Good quenching bitter.
